pros: The campus facilities are modern, well-maintained, and designed to cater to the diverse needs of students. The sport facilities and activities are amazing. Additionally, the state-of-the-art laboratories, research centers, and technology infrastructure enable students to engage in hands-on learning and cutting-edge research.
cons: The university's administrative processes can sometimes be cumbersome and time-consuming. Procedures related to enrollment, financial aid, and academic advising could be streamlined and made more efficient. Improving the responsiveness and clarity of communication from administrative departments would enhance the overall student experience.

review_title: Great students, unclear progression routes for support staff
pros: Great students, most collegues are friendly. Work can be interesting and rewarding.
cons: If you want a secure job as long as you keep your head down you are pretty safe, but if you have any ambition it is not really the place to be if you are not either Senior management or academic. Once you hit the top of your grade there is little hope of progressing, but if you are not careful you can pick up a lot of extra responsibilities without any extra pay. You also have to pay for car parking if you work on campus, which benefits the "working from home" staff as they pay alot less than the full time campus staff. In theory work should be flexible but you can end up feeling the opposite during term time when 8:30am to 6:30pm can be 3-4 days out of 5.

pros: * Flexible work environment * Friendly colleagues
cons: Admin at the school, teams are so bad

review_title: Glossy on the surface, rotten underneath.
pros: The uni is a buzzing place to work. Campus is great, students are engaged. But...
cons:
Bullying, as others have said, is rife and some management join in. If you stand up to being bullied, you become the target. 
HR say the right things but do absolutely nothing. 
They have a system called ‘Confide’, who are a network of staff to talk to if you think you are being bullied. My Confide person was horrified at the treatment I had experienced at the hands of these other members of staff. He confirmed this  was the worst bullying he had come across, and still senior management and HR did nothing., occupational health would not help me, and the bullying continued.
The pay and benefits are good, but this just makes it a cosier place for the bullying to breed. They won’t leave, so their targets have to.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Loughborough, England
pros:
Nice environment, good balance of work and personal life. You can be well supported by the human resources and there are several training useful for your personal development.
Definitely recommended!
cons:
It can be far from the train station of you are commuting from another city.
Rather than the campus, the town is quite small and it does not offer all sort of attraction that I bigger city has.

pros: Fine if you like teaching and don't mind working under pressure for 60 hours + per week.
cons: A mixed bag, some very competitive and asocial colleagues a lot of hierarchy and not uncommon to encounter bullying/ power tripping.  Feels like the 1970s culture never left this place.

review_title: Good university for research but bullying and abuse of power are common in some work environments.
pros:
1. Individual offices for academic staff.
2. Necessary reference management, data analysis and graphing software such as Mendeley and OriginPro are provided and you can install them on your university PC. 
3. Clean, beautiful and safe campus
4. Good cafes and restaurants
5. Good sport facilities (two gyms, pool, pitches...)
6. Good research quality
7. Free public transportation inside the campus
8. Attracting women in STEM
9. There are many development
10. If you work with the right person, the university can be the best place for you to develop yourself both professionally and personally.
cons:
1. Town is too small and can be boring for single people.
2. Starting salary is low for independent research fellows awarded internal university fellowships; their salary is the same as those research associates who are hired by an academic staff's grant/funding. 
3. Still male dominated university
4. Some senior academic members use juniors as their own worker and do not let them to develop and become independent. Of course, it depends who you work with.
5. The opportunity to get the Fellow of Higher Education Academia (FHEA) are given to postdocs without PhD and with a very short-term contact (up to 6 months) but not to research fellows holding prestigious university fellowships (DPF) with longer contracts (more than a year)! 
6. No information was given to new research fellows from the beginning that they have to pass Essential Teaching Skills if they want to be select for FHEA. There are some misinformation in this part. 
7. Female staff in some departments feel they are underestimated by their male colleagues.
8. HR should inform new staff, in particular research fellows, that they have the right to claim their relocation costs. I found this very late as I was not aware of this claim. The relocation claim should been sent to me before in the process of employment, before joining the university.
8. Bullying and abuse of power are the big problems in some research groups. The system is totally failed to protect young, female staff from abuses. Some senior academics even do not care about their authorities and managers' warnings, and keep bullying and abusing junior staff.

pros: Overall great environment to work in  for  most of staff and good modern buildings with up to  date facilities in all areas.
cons: Not all staff groups have the same promotion and development scope due to operational management issues and as a consequence quite a few left my former department which was STEM focussed to take up other work or retire.

pros: Good links with industry, so some networking can provide with industrial partners for research proposals. Very competitive with other universities, hence there is always a motivation, which can be really good.
cons: Some departments can be biased towards some research groups, specially those which are considered the "strength of the department". So if you are in the strength groups, you would love working here, but if you are not it can be quite difficult to survive.

pros:
Energetic ethos provided by students, a spacious campus and sport obsessions.

Cost of living in the East Midlands is cheap

Management is traditionally authoritarian but generally supportive.

Despite the increasing pressures on Higher Education, mostly never forgets it is a university
cons:
If you work in a support service, very poor promotion prospects, basically you need to apply for vacancies which are few and far between.

Management is poor quality (though not necessarily intrusive). Too many academics pretending to be managers - managerialism is rife

review_title: Flexible, Friendly and Relaxed but No career prospects
